climbs.name: Way Too Cold For My Asspen

content.description: .First bolt is a little high. Easy climbing though to first bolt. Crux is going from first bolt to 2nd bolt. Kind of spaced between. Work the crimps to the blank part of the route. Once above the 2nd bolt go for the rentable huge jug hold. Easy climbing to the top.
content.protection: 3 bolts    Shares anchors with bull headed (5.9)
content.location: To the left of Bull Headed (5.9)

content.description: This is the left to right rising crack to the left of Dirty Earnie. It's a little dirty itself and doesn't seem to get much traffic, but it's a fun climb regardless. After clipping the bolt (optional) you'll encounter the sequence of 5.8 moves. After gaining the upper portion of the climb it's a easy jog to the top.
content.protection:
There is one bolt on this route but it really isn't needed. There is a good pocket maybe a foot to the left that takes a decent cam placement and another good pocket after the bolt to the right that takes another. Good gear throughout. Currently has no anchors, either set up a trad belay or finish the easy 5th class arete to the top of dirty earnie and use these anchors to belay from the top. Must be followed due to the nature of the L-R crack.

 Cams - 0.3-#2 Nuts 1-Bolt 2-Bolt Anchor on Top
content.location: Left to Right rising crack just right of Dirty Earnie. You'll see the one bolt about 12 ft up.

climbs.name: Not Too Steep for my Lichen
climbs.fa: Tom Kohlmann, Rich Salm-1990 Ground Up

content.description: From the little spur trail off the old road, this is the center of 3 routes encounted immediately when reaching the rock. Climb a very steep face through huge jugs.  Each jug seems bigger than the last and the left arete is good too.  Rap the route from chains with one rope.

climbs.name: Dirty Earnie
climbs.fa: Gary Johnson,Greg Fossum and Vern Olson-1998

content.description: From the little spur trail off the old road, this is the right most of 3 routes encounted immediately when reaching the rock.  Climb the juggy water trough, with a crux at the first bolt.  Interesting climbing involves jug hauling and even some chimney technique.  Rap from Unknown 2's anchors, with one rope.

From the little spur trail off the old road, this is the leftmost of 3 routes encounted immediately when reaching the rock.  This route starts off low angle, hits a steeper slabby section, and ends on big jugs. 

  Rap from chains, one rope.
Begin up a low angle but dirty slab or traverse up and in from the right on a slightly cleaner ramp.  Move up the blunt arete clipping a few bolts.  Head to an anchor on less steep terrain.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a vertically aligned double bolt anchor.  A third rusty bolt sits slightly up and right of the newer bolts.
content.location: From the popular routes on the north face of Bull Rock, continue right, just around the corner from Slanting Crack.

climbs.name: Bull Crap
climbs.fa: Jim Slichter and Gary Johnson 1995 Ground Up

content.description: Start as for Bull Dyke (5.10). Move up and clip the first bolt. From here you will traverse left across the crystal face to the obvious crack/flake. Follow the crack/flake to its end and the 2-bolt anchor on top.Â
content.protection: Cams- #1-#3   Nuts   1- Bolt   2- Bolt Anchor On Top

content.description: Bull Rock has newer bolted lines on it, as well as a crack climb.  The bolted lines here tend to be steep and juggy.
